title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Oil Company Accountability Act" introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Each individual is treated as having made a $500 payment against the tax for the 2006 taxable year, to be remitted by the Secretary within 30 days. Certain individuals with no adjusted gross income or exceeding $120,000 are not eligible for this rebate. The Oil Company Accountability Act excludes individuals with no income or AGI over $120,000, those eligible for a deduction under section 151, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens from the Energy Tax Rebate. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Oil Company Accountability Act makes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by adding a new item to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 will take effect on the date of the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there will be a revaluation of LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 will take effect upon enactment of the Act, and there will be a revaluation of LIFO inventories for applicable integrated oil companies in their last taxable year ending in 2005. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 will result in a revaluation of LIFO inventories for integrated oil companies in their last taxable year ending in 2005. If the increases under paragraph (1) exceed the taxpayer's cost of goods sold, their gross income for the year will be increased by the excess amount known as the layer adjustment amount. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 will lead to a revaluation of LIFO inventories for integrated oil companies in their last taxable year ending in 2005. Any adjustment required by this section will not be considered a change in method of accounting. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined as the number of barrels of crude oil or barrel-of-oil equivalents represented by the layer. Any adjustment required by this section shall not be treated as a change in method of accounting. No addition to the tax shall be made under section 6655 of the Internal Revenue Code with respect to any underpayment of an installment required to be paid with respect to the taxable year described in subsection (a) to the extent such underpayment was created or increased by this section. The term "applicable integrated oil company" refers to an integrated oil company with specific production and revenue criteria. All persons treated as a single employer under certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are considered as such for this subsection. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code are considered as 1 person, and the rule under section 448(c)(3)(B) applies in the case of a short taxable year. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES WHO ARE DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax. Large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers will not be considered to have paid a tax to a foreign country or possession of the United States if the country does not impose a generally applicable income tax, or if the amount paid exceeds what is determined by regulations. The paragraph discusses the tax treatment of dual capacity taxpayers under the generally applicable income tax imposed by a country or possession. It clarifies that the amount paid should not exceed the determined limit under regulations. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed under the laws of a foreign country on income derived from conducting a trade or business within that country. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company meeting specific criteria for a taxable year. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil for a taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
